I believe that an income tax (or something with a similar result such as a value-added tax) is necessary to discourage people from working too hard.
 
 Let me give as an example the construction industy of a large city. Suppose the industry is operating at capcity. If Mary wants to build a house, she can hire a contractor to do that. Since the city is large and has numerous contractors, and since Mary can compete for contractors just as well as anybody else, her workers will only have to work a negligible amount of overtime to get the job done. Consequently, she will choose to build her house if workers are willing to build her house using non-overtime work for less money than what she is willing to spend on it. But the industry is operating at capacity, so the effect of Mary building her house is that the construction workers of the city will have to work overtime to get her house built along with the other houses, etc., they are building. If in the obvious sense working overtime is half as efficient and twice as unpleasant as non-overtime work, then the net effect of Mary deciding to build her house on the suffering of the construction workers in the city is that these construction workers will suffer an amount they would pay four times what Mary spent in hiring them to avoid! This is undesirable! Without taxation to discourage production, the economy overheats and people have to work too hard.
 
 I would be interested in knowing what branch of macroeconomics deals with this and similar considerations. It wasn't convered in my undergraduate Econ course, but it is so obvious to me surely someone must have thought of this?
